channel.title: Posts on Grant's Tracks
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Grant's Tracks

item.title: Car Caching Along the Backroad of Lamont County
item.description: Car-caching with a buddy in north Lamont County

item.title: A Short Hike Along Mtn Bike Trails East of Goldstick Park
item.description: I returned to these trails with the goal of finding a cache I’d been unable to find in Dec. 2023. Compared to that visit, this summer outing today provided a far different experience - and I loved it.

item.title: Finding a Fairly Remote Cache South of Mandy Lake
item.description: To get to a remote cache today, I walked down familiar trails but then covered ground that I’d only once been near before 10 years ago - and that was in the winter months.

item.title: Ministik Five Meadows to Waskahegan Loop Hike
item.description: I undertook a grand loop hike in the Ministik today, what I call the Five Meadows Hike. It was a gloriously beautiful day to do it too.

item.title: Ministik Geocaching Hike North of 510 and South to Deadfall Alley
item.description: Three of us did a two part hike today, first north of Township Rd 510 and then south to Deadfall Alley

item.title: Ministik Hike to Explore Trails Northeast of Mandy Lake
item.description: In the past I’d walked on stub trails northeast of Mandy Lake and today I wanted to see if they really were actual trails - spoiler alert - there were.

item.title: Walking a Mostly Forgotten Trail Off Spilstead Road
item.description: There are some out of the way trails in the Ministik that start but eventually just peter out into nothing. This is one of them.

item.title: Ministik Hike Near Joseph Lake
item.description: I made the trek down the trails of a corner of the Ministik I seldom visit today.

item.title: Chickakoo Hike With Geocaching Buddies
item.description: After parking at the Chickakoo Equestrian Lot, we proceeded to scour the eastern side of Chickakoo for caches

item.title: Ministik Hike Along Deadfall Alley
item.description: Four of us hiked south from the UofA Access Road gate all the way down Deadfall Alley today.

item.title: Ministik Lake Watery Ice Geocaching Hike
item.description: It’s March and the ice between islands on Ministik Lake can still be walked on. Or can it? Yikes! There’s standing water on a lot of it!

item.title: Ministik Hike to Hide a Geocache
item.description: I hiked down the Mandy Lake road, past the old cabin and shelter to hide a geocache today.

item.title: Ministik Hike to Two Cache Hides Near Ministik Lake
item.description: I’d waited to make the trek for a while. But the weather promised to be great today and and as it turned out it certainly was.

item.title: Shiningbank Lake Group Ice Walk to Geocaches
item.description: Eight of us met at Shiningbank Lake to do a grand loop around the shoreline where geocaches were hidden. First we needed to walk straight across the middle of the lake though. Pucker up and walk!

item.title: Edmonton Science Park to Rundle Park Via Gnarly Mountain Bike Trails
item.description: I really didn’t know what I was getting myself into when I started the loop hike from Science Park, but I not only survived the hilly mountain bike trails I ended up walking on, but I enjoyed the experience.

item.title: Ministik Misasin Trail Geocaching Hike
item.description: This was fun and challenging outing. I was anticipating a LOT more bush whacking than I ended up experiencing.

item.title: Geocaching in Calgary for Specific Caches
item.description: I made a long-awaited trip to Calgary to target finding specific caches across the city.

item.title: Ministik Hike to Replace Cache Container
item.description: One of my cache containers was the victim of a bored coyote so I hiked in to replace it with a new one today.

item.title: Ministik Hike to Spruce Point Geocache
item.description: I walked the familiar route from the UofA Access Road gate to the unfamiliar boggy shoreline of a large pond in the Ministik.

item.title: Car Caching Trip to the Dogpound Area
item.description: Dwaine and I had worked on some challenging puzzles and after we solved them a trip to the Dogpound area of Alberta was in order.

item.title: Geocaching Along the North Saskatchewan River Near Devon
item.description: Two geocaching buddies and I traversed some seldom-walked trails along the North Sask River

item.title: Glory Hills Geocaching Hike
item.description: It was my first time hiking around the trails at in Glory Hills Natural Area. There were a few caches here, but in the end it was the trails that I remember.

item.title: Geocaching and Exploring on the Ministik Misasin Trail
item.description: I’d been on this trail a couple of times before but it’s been a long time since the last visit. It’s named Misasin by fellow geocachings, so I’m going with it. It was fun exploring new sections of it today.

item.title: Geocaching the "Sturgeon River Stroll" Series of Caches
item.description: This is a geocaching outing where I was SO glad to be with other cachers. The first hide was diabolically hard to find and it was Dwaine who spotted it. They weren’t all like that but some were oh so nicely crafty indeed.

item.title: Chickakoo Caching Hike
item.description: I’ve always just loved hiking in the Chickakoo Lake Recreation Area. There’s is a great mix of tree species that line both the well-travelled main trails and the less-travelled “goat tracks”. This was a solo geocaching hike and I found all but one of the caches I looked for today.

item.title: Ministik Hike to Mandy Lake for Two Geocaches
item.description: I traveled down the winding road to Mandy Lake today to find two caches. I was with the cache owner when he hid them, so I’m returning to find them fair and square.

item.title: Riverside Walk: Riverboat Landing to Emily Murphy Park
item.description: The theme today seemed to be bridges and trails during my riverside walk along the North Saskatchewan River today.

item.title: Ministik Hike to Dorward Lake for Two Challenge Caches
item.description: I had multiple goals today: to find a challenge cache near Dorward Lake and to capture as many time lapses as I could in the Dorward Lake area.

item.title: Terwillegar Dog Park to Fort Edmonton Walk
item.description: The walk from the Terwillegar Dog Park to Fort Edmonton takes you over the N Sask River through mountain bike trails and then over the river yet again.

item.title: Blackfoot Hike to Maintain Two Geocaches
item.description: The main purpose of today’s hike was to swap ammo can geocaching containers for lock ’n lock containers. These caches were hidden quite a distance from parking in the Blackfoot / Cooking Lake Recreational Area.

item.title: Ministik Hike to the Twins Cache
item.description: I made walk over early spring, still somewhat snowy ground to a remote cache today

item.title: Ministik Hike From Stove Lake Trailhead to New Caches
item.description: Four of us crunched through the snow, on trail and off to find geocaches in the area accessible from the Stove Lake trailhead in the Ministik Bird Sanctuary.

item.title: Mactaggart Geocaching Hike
item.description: The four of us traversed a good portion of the MacTaggart Sanctuary today looking for geocaches

item.title: Hike to North Sask River Geocache Hides and MacTaggart Sanctuary
item.description: The five of us tackled some steep slopes to get to some geocache hides along the North Sask River and after that hiked through the MacTaggart Sanctuary to find more geocaches

item.title: Whitemud Ravine Geocaching Hike
item.description: I traversed the snowy inclined trails of the Whitemud Ravine today with a couple of geocaching buddies.

item.title: Geocaching Hike to Mandy Lake
item.description: I followed the road to Mandy Lake to find one cache and do some maintenance on one of my own

item.title: Hike in the Northern Section of the Ministik
item.description: I hiked on a kind of disjointed trail today with a buddy where I have a string of caches hidden.

item.title: Running of the Bulls
item.description: See what a fairly remote section of the Hornbeck Recreation Area northwest of Edson, Alberta looks like a the end of September as two geocachers do a loop trek on overgrown trails.

item.title: Islet Lake Kayak Paddle
item.description: Still very new to kayaking, I had great paddle around Islet Lake today.

item.title: Maiden Voyage of the Delta 12.10
item.description: This was the first time I was out on my new Delta 12.10 kayak. Woah, Nelly! Here we go!

item.title: Kayaking on Islet Lake
item.description: My first forays in my inflatable kayak were tentative, but memorable all the same.

item.title: Ministik Hike Past the Northeast Passage and Return
item.description: Hiking to one of my geocache hides to do some maintenance was my excuse to experience a beautiful day in a remote, beautiful place.

item.title: Bluejay - Charron Community Cemetery
item.description: A visit to the well-maintained Bluejay - Charron Community Cemetery northeast of Atmore, Alberta.

item.title: Ministik Geocaching Hike to New Hides
item.description: I hiked in what was for me a new area in the Ministik today and that’s always fun.

item.title: St. Anthony of Padua Church and Cemetery
item.description: St. Anthony of Padua Church and Cemetery are located southwest of Medicine Hat, Alberta. The church has fallen into disrepair and seems to stand as a symbol of a past reality now fading.

item.title: Aetna Cemetery
item.description: A visit to Aetna, a hamlet in Cardston County, Alberta.

item.title: Prospy Cemetery
item.description: Prospy Cemetery was generally unkept with graves markers lightly scattered across the small enclosure. Despite that, one grave marker in particular caught my eye.

item.title: Searching for Spring Along the Road to Mandy Lake
item.description: An early spring hike in the Ministik Bird Sanctuary southeast of Edmonton. Will I find some spring to help thaw my winter-frozen brain?

item.title: Ministik Mandy Lake Loop Hike
item.description: I did a loop hike over what has become very familiar ground today. But even on familar paths, the experience of them is always changing.

item.title: Seven Persons Cemetery
item.description: Seven Persons is a hamlet in Cypress County, Alberta about 20 km southwest of Medicine Hat. There are various stories about how the hamlet got it’s name.

item.title: Hillcrest Cemetery
item.description: Hillcrest Cemetery is memorable partly because of the location and partly because of the mine disaster of 1914 that took so many lives.

item.title: The Red Chair
item.description: For almost a decade a single red folding chair has been stationed at a lookout over Williams Lake in the Ministik Bird Santuary. The landscape is in constant flux around it, but the red chair remains.

item.title: Ministik Geocaching Hike to the South End of Oliver Lake
item.description: I walked along the crusty snow first on familiar trails, then off trail on new ground to get to the south end of Oliver Lake today.

item.title: Ministik Mandy Lake Hike Over Snowy Trails
item.description: I had to do some maintenance on a cache near Mandy Lake in the Ministik Bird Sanctuary and had great outing walking along the still snowy trails to get to it.

item.title: Ministik Mandy Lake to Waskahegan Fire Tower Geocaching Hike Via Trails and Lake Ice
item.description: This was a memorable day of geocaching for a few remote caches int he Ministik Bird Sanctuary.

item.title: Hike to the Ministik Fireplace and Return via Red Chair Lookout
item.description: I made the snowy walk to scout out a geocache hide, realized I wasn’t going to be able to get to it, so continued on to visit the Ministik fireplace and Red Chair Lookout.

item.title: Ministik Hike to Dorward Lake for Two Remote Geocaches
item.description: I had a glorious trudge through (not over) the trails to Dorward Lake today to find two caches.

item.title: Driving on Lac Ste Anne Ice to Find Farming Island Geocaches
item.description: Hugh and I were planning on walking over the ice to the caches on Farming Island on Lac St Anne. But we saw ice fishers on the ice, so we drove instead.

item.title: Ice Walking to Island Geocaches on Oliver Lake
item.description: I met my buddy Hugh and we spent hours walking over crusty lake ice to find geocachings hidden on islands on Oliver Lake in the Ministik Bird Sanctuary

item.title: Ministik Hike from Mandy Lake to Dorward Lake Over Lake Ice
item.description: I had an excellent walk over hardened trail snow and lake ice to get to remote cache in the Ministik Bird Sanctuary

item.title: A Satisfying Hike Over Lake Ice to the Domino “Puzzle” Cache
item.description: A geocaching buddy Hugh and I trudge across lake ice early in March, 2021 to get to an island on which a “puzzle” geocache was hidden.

item.title: The Endless Loop of Decision
item.description: Two very different stories share one identical, fundamentally important message.

item.title: My Beautiful Teacup from Bizen
item.description: I had the rare opportunity to visit with two potters who made Bizen pottery in Okayama Prefecture in Japan. The purposely rough, charred style of pottery conjures an aesthetic called wabi-sabi.

item.title: My Ugly Mug from Tobe
item.description: I still have my “ugly mug” from Tobe, Ehime Prefecture, Japan. I think of it as an important momento of my time living in Japan but I still think it’s ugly.

item.title: Zettelkasten: the Promise of A Truly Effective Method of Learning
item.description: A brief introduction to the Zettelkasten method of note making as described in How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens.

item.title: StoryMapJS - Part 3 - Sharing a StoryMap
item.description: In Part 3, the final part of the series, we cover how to share your StoryMap with others.

item.title: The Meal
item.description: The title suggests this post is about a meal, but the topic is really about adapting to new and different realities.

item.title: StoryMapJS - Part 2 Building a StoryMap
item.description: In Part 2 of a three-part series we cover how to build StoryMap slides.

item.title: A Google Earth Web Tour of Cambridge Bay
item.description: Tour a few places in Cambridge Bay using Google Earth Web and Google Streetview images.

item.title: The Anti-Climactic Ice-Fishing Excursion
item.description: These are my memories about an ill-fated group ice-fishing trip by plane from Cambridge Bay to somewhere on the artic tundra. Everyone came out completely safe and unharmed, but let’s just say that no fishing of any kind happened.

item.title: StoryMapJS Tutorial - Part 1 - Introduction
item.description: This is Part 1 of a three-part series on how to use StoryMapJS. Here I’ll introduce you to the software and review examples of what it can do.

item.title: A Trip to Taloyoak
item.description: A complete - fairly long - account of a trip from Cambridge Bay, Nunavut to Gjoa Haven, Pelly Bay and finally Taloyak.

item.title: Snowblind on a Quad
item.description: During my 10-month stay in Cambridge Bay, any chance to get out of town to was a chance not only to explore, but also escape.

item.title: Out on the Land
item.description: Sure, it was just a quad ride out of town, but it was also my first chance to escape the what was becoming the prison of being in Cambridge Bay for too long.

item.title: Taking Pics
item.description: This little piece is about a jaunt out of Cambridge Bay just across a small bay to the east where the rotting hulk of a boat sits on the shoreline.

item.title: Sleeping in an Igloo
item.description: After an igloo building bee, and hearing the stories from the brave women who were first to try out sleeping overnight in the little dome, it was the guys turn.

item.title: Building an Igloo
item.description: Helping to build and later sleep in an igloo still remains a strong memory from my time in Cambridge Bay.

item.title: Traveling to Cambridge Bay
item.description: This is my account of the trip north from Saskatoon, SK, to Calgary, AB, then Edmonton, AB, then Yellowknife, NWT and finally Cambridge Bay, NWT (now Nunavut).

item.title: Where is Cambridge Bay?
item.description: This post is all about Cambridge Bay, Nunavut, Canada. Be sure to check out the Google Earth Web tour at the end of the post.

item.title: Winter Walk to the Waskahegan Fire Tower
item.description: A hike to a fairly remote fire tower in the Ministik Bird Sanctuary southeast of Edmonton is brought to life with StoryMapJS, software that combines maps with images and text.

item.title: An Example of TimelineJS in Action
item.description: Using a restrospective of REM’s discography, this post walks through the capabilities of TimelineJS a piece of timeline software hosted by Northwestern University’s Knight Lab.

item.title: Monitor Cemetery
item.description: Located in a large plot on the side of a long, sloping hill, I happened to visit Monitor Cemetery when the surrounding crops were in full bloom, justaposing new life with inevitable death.

item.title: Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church and Cemetery
item.description: Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church and Cemetery lies 32 kms northeast of the town of Athabasca, Alberta and serves the Spruce Valley district.

item.title: Quad Trek to Grizzly Ridge Tower
item.description: I’d been “map-dreaming” for literally years about making the trek to Grizzly Ridge Tower. I’d even tried and failed once foiled by muddy roads. But because of the kindness of friends, I was finally able to get there.

item.title: St. Laurence Anglican Church - Monitor, Alberta
item.description: St. Laurence Anglican Church is located in the hamlet of Monitor, Alberta. Constructed in 1915, it is registered in the Canadian Register of Historic Places.

item.title: Hike to Oliver Lake to Find Two New Geocaches
item.description: It seemed as if I was floating along the Ministik trails today.

item.title: Siracky Chapel
item.description: A tiny, quaint chapel built from stone.

item.title: St. Demetrius Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Jaroslaw)
item.description: St. Demetrius Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Jaroslaw) is a compact structure which stands near a well-kept cemetery.

item.title: Russo Greek Orthodox Church of St. Michael the Archangel
item.description: This church is one of the earlier examples of an “open-dome” cruciform church: a large, single central dome is built on an octagonal base

item.title: Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary Ukrainian Catholic Church (Star-Peno)
item.description: A visit to the Blessed Virgin Mary Ukrainian Catholic Church (Star-Peno) and cemetary with a timelapse video and photo gallery.

item.title: Protection of the Blessed Virgin Mary Ukrainian Catholic Church (Krakow)
item.description: The history of this church echos many others in the area: early churches built, destroyed by fire in this case multiple times and always rebuilt again.

item.title: St. John The Baptist Russo-Greek Catholic Orthodox Church (Farus)
item.description: This church stands at the top of a small hill overlooking a cemetery and farmland beyond.

item.title: Church of the Archangel St. Michael
item.description: As was the case with many churches in the area, a history of nationalism inherited from the “old country” affected the lives after settling half way around the world in Canada.

item.title: St. John Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Sachava)
item.description: Like a number of other churches in the area, differences of belief and cultural background have separated groups of people who originally worshiped together.

item.title: Presentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Ukrainian Catholic Church (Delph)
item.description: Another immaculate church in that speaks to the devotion and work ethic of the people from Europe who settled this part of the province.

item.title: St. Michael The Archangel Roman Catholic Church
item.description: This church provides an interesting historical twist: here’s an example of a town being named after a church.

item.title: St. Nicholas Orthodox Church (Bukowina)
item.description: Built in 1900 after three years of labour, this church has the distinction of being the oldest original church in Lamont county.

item.title: Holy Trinity Orthodox Church (Sunland)
item.description: This church, bell-tower, and ajoining cemetery continue the theme of being well-kept and picturesque.

item.title: Holy Trinity Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Kahwin)
item.description: The dome and supporting cupolas of this church are a distinctive bronze colour.

item.title: St. Michael the Archangel Ukrainian Catholic Church
item.description: Like so many others, this church is an example of a structure rebuilt after a previous church succumbed to fire. Now in need of some repair, the building is still an imposing structure.

item.title: Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church (Skaro)
item.description: The church and the surrounding grounds are expansive and impressive.

item.title: Holy Trinity Russo Orthodox Church (Old Wostok)
item.description: In 1987 the first Orthodox liturgy on Canadian soil was celebrated near this church site. Completed in 1899, this church was the first Orthodox Church in Canada.

item.title: St. John the Baptist Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Peno)
item.description: The more you read about the history of rural churches, the more you see instances of parishioners breaking off from a congregation to build a new church and form a new congregation.

item.title: Nativity of the Mother of God Ukrainian Catholic Church
item.description: A quaint church has as beautiful, imposing bell tower and well-kept cemetery beside it.

item.title: Holy Ascension Russo-Greek Orthodox Church (Skaro)
item.description: This parish can be traced back to 1897–1898, making it one of the ﬁrst Russo-Greek Orthodox parishes in Canada.

item.title: Exaltation of the Holy Cross Ukrainian Catholic Church (Skaro)
item.description: This church is extremely impressive. Almost everything about it seems to stand out: the form, the surroundings and how well it is maintained.

item.title: All the Diamonds in This World
item.description: A winter walk over lake ice to Birch Lake Isle near Innisfree, Alberta.

item.title: Roman Catholic Church of the Precious Blood
item.description: Although mass is only held here once a year, this church remains in pretty good shape.

item.title: St. Demetro Ukrainian Catholic Church
item.description: The present church is an architectural departure when compared to other rural churches in the area. But when you read about the history of past buildings being lost to fire, you realize that compact, practical buildings may be the wise choice in the long run.

item.title: Russo-Greek Orthodox Catholic Church of St. James
item.description: Russo-Greek Orthodox Catholic Church of St. James is one of the oldest churches in Lamont County.

item.title: St. Mary’s Church of Shishkovitzy
item.description: St. Mary’s Church of Shishkovitzy is a very well-maintained church and stands on the same piece of land that housed an original structure built from 1898 to 1903, before Alberta became a province.

item.title: "Spas Moskalyk"
item.description: The “Spas Moskalyk” church is an example of historical building almost slipping off into oblivion. This one didn’t slip away, but was saved by the local residents.

item.title: Tofield Cemetery
item.description: Tofield Cemetery is a large, well-kept enclosure about 1.8 kms north of Tofield on highway 843.

item.title: Wilhelmina Lutheran Church
item.description: Wilhelmina Evangelical Lutheran Church near Hay Lakes is nicely-built and obviously well-kept church.

item.title: Crooked Trees
item.description: I found out about the “Crooked Trees” from my sister so I made a point of visiting on my way back to Edmonton from Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. My scientific opinion?: “They’re weird!”

item.title: Hike up Cardinal Divide Ridge
item.description: Although not at all easy to get to even by vehicle, the Cardinal Divide is a memorable place to visit.

item.title: Ministik South Recon Hike
item.description: This recon hike was made and the blog post written early in my explorations of the Ministik Bird Sanctuary. It’s fun for me to relive the experience these days when the area is well-known to me.

item.title: Blackfoot Islet Lake Hike for "Cigar" Caches
item.description: A hike to inner depths of the Cooking Lake - Blackfoot Provincial Recreation Area. Starting from the Islet Lake Staging Area, I was on the hunt for ‘cigar’ caches.

item.title: Climb to the Summit of Folding Mountain
item.description: A made the memorable climb to the summit of Folding Mountain mid-August, 2010.

item.title: Hike to Lusk Creek Ridge Central Summit
item.description: It was my first ever visit to Kananaskis where I made the very memorable off-trail climb to the central summit along Lusk Creek Ridge. It was July 1, Canada Day, too!

item.title: Hike to the Summit of Mt. Louie
item.description: Grande Cache in the distance as seen from the summit of Mt.

item.title: Hike up Mt. Stearn near Grande Cache
item.description: We arrived in Grande Cache wanting to do some hiking and chose almost randomly to climb Mt. Stearn. Boy, did pick a day for a workout!

item.title: Blackfoot Hike (Wanisan Lake)
item.description: A second visit to Cooking Lake – Blackfoot Recreational Area in two days. After a fresh snowfall, I broke trail to out of the way places that were brand new to me.

item.title: Blackfoot Geocaching (Waskahegan)
item.description: A memorable day of geocaching in the Cooking Lake Blackfoot Recreational Area. I was new to geocaching and this area was completely new to me at this time. The experiences of the day really made an impression on
